case. Corrections according last EXFOR rules and
Dict. Added thermal cross section data based on cross
section curve approximations, sample, method and doi.
Digitized the data. Subentries 10-33 were added.

bib_record.title: The Slow Neutron Cross Sections of Indium, Gold, Silver, Antimony, Lithium, and Mercury as Measured with a Neutron Beam Spectrometer

free_txt: Compiler's comment: Plots were digitized vs. neutron
time of flight in  microsec/meter and converted to
energy by compiler using the relation
E = (72.3/t)**2 eV which gives the neutron
energy for a timing t, microsec/meter from. Formula
was taken from Phys. Rev. 71, 165 (1947) and verified
using the method of visual inspection. Transmission
data are more reliable, while cross section scale is
less obvious.
The variations of the slow neutron
transmissions of In, Au, Ag, Sb, Li, and Hg have been
investigated as a function of the time-of-flight of
the incident neutrons for a 5.4-meter path by use of
a neutron beam spectrometer.
If the cross section of aluminum is assumed to be
1.5x10**(-24) cm2/atom, and that of fluorine
2.5x10**(-24) cm2/atom and these cross sections are
assumed constant over the energy interval studied,
then the absorption due to the aluminum and the
fluorine will be equivalent to a reduction in the
transmission to T=0.938 for the 0.862 g/cm2 sample
and to T=0.826 for the 4.85 g/cm2 sample. The
experimental results then indicate that the slow
neutron cross section of lithium follows a 1/v law
and may be expressed as the sum of a constant term
(1.7+- 0.2) ]*10**-24 cm2/atom if the cross section
of fluorine is assumed to be constant at 2.5x10**24
cm2/atom. E is the neutron energy in eV.
Cross section curve calculations.
Fluorine cross sections.
This salt was tightly packed in an aluminum container
such that there were 4.85 g/cm2 of LiF and 0.418
g/cm2 of aluminum in the beam for the thicker sample
and 0.862 g/cm2 of LiF and 0.418 g/cm2 of aluminum in
the beam for the thinner sample. The lithium fluoride
was obtained from the City Chemical Corporation and
was of analytical reagent grade. The salt was dried
at 120 degrees C for 48 hours before being packed in
the container.
Page 169.
Outside resonances, the cross section from the
experimental transmission T by using the formula
T=exp(-n sigma), where n is the number of atoms per
cm2 in the sample.
Resolution width was approximately 20 microsec/meter.

preliminary run on the thin sample in the thermal
region gave sufficient data to indicate the thickness
of the sample which would give best results in this
region. Therefore, the thick sample was cut
approximately in half and a sample containing 7.84
g/cm2 was used for the rest of the measurements an
